bioghist.p: Herbert Booth Smith (1883-1967) was the son of Rev. Joseph Addison Smith. Smith received his arts degree in 1905 from Washington University and his A.M. degree from Princeton in 1908. He graduated from the Princeton Theological Seminary the following year. Smith was ordained as a Presbyterian minister in 1909 and took a pastorate in Rochester, New York, and later Knoxville, Tennessee. In 1916 he moved to Los Angeles to take the pulpit of Immanuel Presbyterian Church. Smith was a past president of the Los Angeles ministerial association and a director of the Los Angeles Board of Church Extension. He was moderator of the Presbytery of Union in 1915 and of the Presbytery of Los Angeles in 1928. In 1913 he was a delegate to the Waldensian Synod which met in Italy. He was also a commissioner to the meetings of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church held in St. Louis (1919), Columbus, Ohio, (1925), San Francisco (1927), and Pittsburgh (1931).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Herbert Booth Smith. Materials include: sermons by Smith and others; printed materials and text of speeches given by Smith on alcoholism; and printed materials related to the annual congregational meetings of the Ventura Community Church, 1961-1969. The collection also includes papers related to Smith's coursework at San Francisco Theological Seminary and a chapter of Smith's thesis on Thomas Fraser. The collection also includes originals and transcripts of letters by Thomas Fraser written to his wife in 1864. Fraser was the subject of Smith's thesis.
